question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to?
inference:
Let the rotation be given by the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ -b & a \end{pmatrix}.$  Then

$$\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ -b & a \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix} \Rightarrow \begin{pmatrix} 13a \\ -13b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix} \Rightarrow \begin{cases} 13a = 5 \\\ -13b = -12 \end{cases} \Rightarrow \begin{cases} a = \frac{5}{13} \\\ b = \frac{12}{13} \end{cases}.$$

Therefore, the rotation takes $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to

$$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix}.$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix}}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus,
\[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
\[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
